content:
This is probably a very naive question, but I feel I am confused by something.

Assuming enough choice, an infinite set AAA has the property that A≅A⊔AA\cong A\sqcup AA≅A⊔A (the disjoint union of two copies of A). However, no such bijection can be natural, in the sense that there can't be a natural transformation, restricted to the subcategory of infinite sets, whose components are said isomorphisms αA:A≅A⊔A\alpha_A : A \cong A\sqcup AαA​:A≅A⊔A. This for a very elementary reason, the identity functor preserves some (co)limits that the functor Set→Set:X↦X⊔X{\sf Set} \to {\sf Set} : X \mapsto X\sqcup XSet→Set:X↦X⊔X does not preserve.

Now, does this obstruction mean that given a small category CCC, there can't be a natural isomorphism F≅F⊔FF\cong F\sqcup FF≅F⊔F for F:C→SetF : C \to SetF:C→Set, but only some unnatural bijections FA≅FA⊔FAFA\cong FA\sqcup FAFA≅FA⊔FA as soon as FAFAFA is infinite?

I am confused too: while AAA and A⊔AA \sqcup AA⊔A are equi-inhabited, there is no bijection. Sure, you can use choice to pick a particular f:A→A⊔Af : A \rightarrow A\sqcup Af:A→A⊔A, and there's an obvious map g:A⊔A→Ag : A\sqcup A \rightarrow Ag:A⊔A→A, but I don't see any amount of choice that would let you get f;g:A⊔A→A⊔Af ; g : A\sqcup A \rightarrow A\sqcup Af;g:A⊔A→A⊔A be the identity. The map ggg forgets all the choices that fff made.

@Jacques Carette: you can replace the set AAA with the cardinal ∣A∣|A|∣A∣; the addition of two infinite cardinals is their maximum (assuming choice), so that ∣A∣+∣A∣=∣A∣|A| + |A| = |A|∣A∣+∣A∣=∣A∣. The explicit bijections are then given by the definition of cardinality, and the bijections constructed by cardinal arithmetic.

Jacques Carette said:

I am confused too: while AAA and A⊔AA \sqcup AA⊔A are equi-inhabited, there is no bijection. Sure, you can use choice to pick a particular f:A→A⊔Af : A \rightarrow A\sqcup Af:A→A⊔A, and there's an obvious map g:A⊔A→Ag : A\sqcup A \rightarrow Ag:A⊔A→A, but I don't see any amount of choice that would let you get f;g:A→A⊔A→A→A⊔Af ; g : A \rightarrow A\sqcup A \rightarrow A \rightarrow A\sqcup Af;g:A→A⊔A→A→A⊔A be the identity. The map ggg forgets all the choices that fff made.

Of course the bijection isn't going to involve the canonical codiagonal map A⊔A→AA \sqcup A \to AA⊔A→A, since that map is not injective...

Nathanael Arkor said:

Jacques Carette: you can replace the set AAA with the cardinal ∣A∣|A|∣A∣; the addition of two infinite cardinals is their maximum (assuming choice), so that ∣A∣+∣A∣=∣A∣|A| + |A| = |A|∣A∣+∣A∣=∣A∣. The explicit bijections are then given by the definition of cardinality, and the bijections constructed by cardinal arithmetic.

This is exactly what I meant, sorry for the misunderstanding :smile:

Now, does this obstruction mean that given a small category CCC, there can't be a natural isomorphism F≅F⊔FF\cong F\sqcup FF≅F⊔F, but only some unnatural bijections FA≅FA⊔FAFA\cong FA\sqcup FAFA≅FA⊔FA as soon as FAFAFA is infinite?

If you take the unique endofunctor F:1→1F : 1 \to 1F:1→1 on the terminal category (or the initial category), then F≅F⊔FF \cong F \sqcup FF≅F⊔F.
(Or is FFF supposed to be a functor into Set\mathrm{Set}Set?)
I think the question was going to be asked more generally, but for the latter half to make sense it needs to be a setting where infinite objects are a meaningful concept.
whoops, a part is missing; F:C→SetF : C \to {\sf Set}F:C→Set
Ah, cardinals, that makes more sense. I did say I was confused (by the phrasing of the question).
If CCC is the empty category, then there is a natural isomorphism between the two functors.
Which really only means you will at least need some nontriviality condition on CCC or FFF.
(Same with any constant functor to an infinite set.)
@Nathanael Arkor exactly what I expected (also, if CCC is discrete, or something? In that case, naturality in an empty condition on a family of maps)
(These conditions are all described by "FFF is constant on connected components of CCC".)
FAFAFA can even be FA=A×SFA = A \times SFA=A×S for some fixed infinite set SSS
